# Draft:Mnawar Mohammed

Mnawar J. Mohammed (Arabic: منوّر ج. محمد) is a Lebanese copywriter, creative translator, and entrepreneur.
He is best known as the founder of CopyArabia, a content creation and Arabic transcreation agency, and the author of several books on advertising, creative translation, and digital marketing, including Fundamentals of Copywriting (2020) and The Fundamentals of Creative Translation (2021)01.
Early life and education
Mohammed graduated from the Lebanese University with a bachelor's degree in Media and Advertising23.
Career
Mohammed began his career in 2003, working in several multinational advertising agencies in Beirut and Dubai45.
In 2014, he founded CopyArabia, a creative agency specializing in Arabic copywriting and transcreation. As the founder and creative director, he focused on improving Arabic advertising standards and launched the awareness campaign #ArabicComesFirst to highlight poor use of Arabic in regional advertising6.
In addition to CopyArabia, Mohammed works as a creative consultant for international brands entering Middle Eastern and North African markets7.
Publications
* Fundamentals of Copywriting (2020) – A guide to Arabic advertising writing. ArabAd magazine described it as the first book of its kind in Arabic advertising, based on over two decades of professional experience8.
* The Fundamentals of Creative Translation (2021) – A reference on the differences between literal and creative translation for advertising texts. Al Joumhouria newspaper noted that the book helps copywriters and translators adapt global campaigns to local cultures9.
* Digital Marketing Secrets: Behind Every Successful Campaign (2023) – A practical framework for designing and executing digital marketing campaigns10.
* A to Z Copywriting Online Course (2024) – An online masterclass for aspiring copywriters. ArabAd reported that the course is built on over twenty years of advertising experience11.
Media and public commentary
Mohammed has frequently commented on gender representation and stereotypes in Arab advertising. In an interview with Ahwal Media, he described how controversy is often used in Lebanese ads to drive visibility, while advocating for more ethical creative standards12.
